author: herculeshd96
title: Mental Health
body:
Hi, have been a sufferer of Depression anxiety and panic attacks for the past year.  
I got so bad that I was introduced to Inclusion Thurrock and was introduced to a guy called Ian who was my therapist for the past 6/8 months I can thank him enough for just being at the end of a phone.  
I went from the bottom of the barrel to the top.  
Thank you.  
So if any body out there who is suffering from Mental Health then don’t suffer in silence give Inclusion Thurrock a call they helped me and I don’t know where I would be now with out them.

author: Thepinkhistorian
title: My life is on hold
body:
I've been attending rheumatology for years. I was diagnosed with a rare condition in 2018 and still don't have a treatment plan. This rare condition means I am at high risk for blood clots. When I was diagnosed my case was taken over by the lead consultant of the clinic. This condition is usually secondary to an autoimmune or connective tissue disease but my consultant has only run standard blood tests and refuses to investigate further. Instead I was diagnosed with fibromyalgia, despite never been tested for that.  
My rheumatologist keeps asking about a symptom that I've never had but they seem convinced I should. Doesn't take notes during our appointments. Has repeatedly told me that I am not eligible for treatment because I'm able to look after myself.  
In 2018 my consultant mentioned a specialist in my condition in England but since then refuses to tell me who this specialist is or how I can get referred to them. I've stated that I would pay privately to see a specialist but they have subsequently said they don't know who the specialist is or if there even is one because the condition is rare.  
I cannot work and live in pain every day and consistently have high levels of inflammation throughout my body. I dislocate several joints every year. While they have agreed in person that I likely had an overactive immune system attacking my body, it's been noted my condition is stable and I'd be reviewed in a year. I have multiple health conditions and attend other departments. My treatment in those departments has been stalled because my other consultants believe there is an overarching issue which needs to be addressed. I've exhausted every other option and all have pointed me back to rheumatology.  
In 2021 I asked for a second opinion and was told that there was no mechanism to do so as no one had ever requested one before with this consultant. It took several months and with help from the Patient Client Council, for the consultant to organise a MDM with other rheumatologists. I was only informed about the MDM after it had taken place and my rheumatologist presented my case to it. I had no confidence in my rheumatologist presenting the facts of my case since they have in the past consistently confused me with other patients. The result of the MDM was that there was no unifying diagnosis and I would be reviewed in a year.  
I have had to ask my GP to refer me to another trust just to get a second opinion as I've been told it is not possible to see anyone else in his department. This means I'm now once again at the bottom of a waiting list.  
I am a young woman and my life is on hold until I can be diagnosed. I have been told I cannot receive surgery for another condition until this rheumatological issue is diagnosed. I've also been told that the possible diagnoses could have an impact on fertility or pregnancy outcomes but nothing can be done while there is no definitive diagnosis. My entire life has become dependent on the 15 minutes I spent in one appointment. I don't know what to do anymore.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: requirementre73
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: My experience was first class
body:
I was admitted onto the Female Surgical Ward following severe abdominal pain.  
My experience began in the Emergency Department where I encountered a long wait. However, my experience was first class other than this. The staff were under terrible pressure but still managed to provide a top grade service. The staff were excellent and incredibly pleasant as they tried to do their level best.  
Up on the Female Surgical Ward it has been really very good. All the staff have been wonderful and incredibly caring – even when under such pressure. The surgeon who dealt with me was excellent. However, every staff member who has been involved in my care in any way has been first class.  
Other than the pressures the health service is under, I have no other suggestions for improvement. The ward has been very clean and well kept.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: nuttyjack
title: Made to queue outside in the cold
body:
Arrived approx 15 minutes early for 2pm visiting on Arethusa Ward, where my husband had been admitted as an emergency 2 days earlier. On my previous visits on questioning at the entrance, I had only said that I was expected on Arethusa ward and I went straight through, which I was, because I had arranged to speak to a doctor, but this time I said that I was visiting my husband. I was then told that I must join a long queue of people waiting outside, until vising began at 2pm. I had noticed this long line of people waiting in the cold when I had visited before, or when I had attended out patients with my husband, standing outside in the cold and sometimes the rain, and wondered what they were waiting for, Well, I replied that I would not join the queue, that I would go inside to the coffee shop and have a warm drink as I usually do and wait sitting in a comfortable chair until 2pm as I am entitled to do as someone in my early 70's.  
At this point in the pandemic, when most of us are vaccinated, and are given masks to wear as we enter the hospital, I think it is totally wrong for Medway hospital to stop the visitors from entering the hospital until exactly visiting time and make them queue outside in the cold in winter!

author: swingxk69
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Some confusion with pregnancy appointments during Covid
body:
Following the birth of my child, I would just like to take a moment to comment on my whole pregnancy experience.  
The first thing I would like to say is that you don’t get seen as much due to COVID-19. I found it a real difficulty getting appointments for scans etc. as the booking system was quite inadequate in my opinion. For example, one of the difficulties I encountered was that I was told that there were no appointments available but was then subsequently contacted and asked why I missed the appointment. Clearly this issue with communication needs addressing. With this being my first child it made it quite confusing for me when it really should have been straightforward.  
Moving to the delivery itself – it was very quick and I had no time for an epidural. The staff were all absolutely amazing and incredibly reassuring. Elaine and Olivia downstairs were particularly great.  
Up on the ward it has been grand so far – I haven’t really been up long. All the midwives and rest of the staff have been great. I am particularly happy about the relaxation of the COVID-19 visiting restrictions as it makes such a difference to the experience having your partner allowed in to visit.  
Other than the issues with booking appointments I have no improvements to suggest.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: cuberp75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Nurses both caring and attentive
body:
My hospital stay began at the Emergency Department at Daisy Hill. The wait was a bit long, but I expected this. The staff were all great and made up for this long wait with their excellent care. I spent all night on a gurney before being admitted to the Female Surgical Ward due to a hernia.  
Up on the Female Surgical Ward it has been really really good. The staff have all been really very attentive and incredibly caring. I remember the anaesthetist to be particularly excellent.  
All the girls on the ward have been lovely – every single one of them.  
The only problem I have had has been the tea and coffee – in my opinion it has been really bad – absolutely rotten. Maybe it was just me after my operation, however I just haven’t been able to face it again.  
Other than this, my care couldn’t have been any better or improved in any way.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: dracoeq93
title: Excellent care and staff
body:
Just to say that I thought that everything they have done for me has been excellent. I recently came out of hospital but didn’t manage to book an appointment with the clinic at that time. I didn’t feel up to calling them immediately but when I did, they went out of their way to get me an appointment within a few days. They are very professional and well organised.  
I am a regular patient here and I cannot fault the service, my results were given to me there and then and everything explained to me.  
The only thing I think that would make it better is an explanation of jargon and technical words and abbreviations in the letter I received. This was explained to me in the appointment, but I cannot remember it all. Perhaps something at the bottom of the letter to explain, I feel that if I understood better I would be able to look after myself better.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: homamef56
title: Thank you to podiatry
body: Just a thank you to the staff at Arches Health & Wellbeing Centre for their advice and help with my care plan, they always get me what I need. They are professional and caring and I have a plan and further appointments in place.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: carinadz75
title: Dismissive of the pain I had
body:
It is the 5th consultant I saw in 3 months about the lump I have on my back. The 6th or 7th time I have been in the Altnagelvin Hospital in Derry, and I have never experienced anything like this. In fact, my experience has been so pleasant in the Fracture Clinic that I had with me today a card and a box of chocolate to thank the staff there - consultants and nurses alike - for their kindness and professionalism.  
The reason why I am writing today is because the recent consultation with the doctor was dismissive of the pain I had and the reason why I came, I personally found the language used to be abusive and described it as such, and critical of the diagnostic of other consultants and cynical in the way my questions were answered. As soon as I used that word, abusive, a nurse was asked to come to the room, and the doctor commented that it was them who feels abused by me. I left the appointment crying, and as I was sitting in the entrance of the hospital to look at the papers handed by the nurse who was in the room with us to complain if I wished to (they spoke to me right after I left the room), another nurse came to me, not knowing who I was, but as I explained what happened, they shared that another staff member who was in the room was also left shaken after this consultation. It is unacceptable to have a member of medical staff act in such a way. This is the reason why I am writing today.On to the story: I had a conversation previously on the phone over a month ago with the doctor. Already over the phone I had a feeling they were being a bit dismissive but didn't think much of it until I arrived at the hospital. There was the doctor and two additional members of staff as I arrived in the consultation room. I barely sat in the chair to speak about my problem when I was asked to see where it was hurting. The lump is on my left buttcheek.I was asked a few times to show exactly where the lump was and they pushed with a finger and it was painful. This was done a few times and I shared it was hurting here at this same place. They then asked one of the other staff members to also see and touch it too.As I sat down, he asked how big I thought this lump was - dating from 20 years ago- so I said it was perhaps the size of a golf ball, and that I wasn't sure. They started to read the report from previous doctors, making comments for each one of them in what I felt was a mocking tone. Said it was evaluated that the lump is 3 to 5 cm. I asked what that meant, and how big it was. They replied 3 to 5 cm, with additional comments.When the MRI scan was read - which was also read to me by the previous consultant who is the one who booked me an appointment with the surgical department - they said that they actually saw no lump whatsoever. There is no lump. And just kept repeating that when I was speaking of the pain and the fact that they had touched a point where I was hurt.The whole conversation then turned to an altercation where I felt ridiculed and that I had to justify myself for the pain I had, but also for asking, granted the fact that they see no lump then what then what to do?They continued to make dismissive remarks and this is when I actually said that I believe we didn't start this consultation from the right foot, that maybe it is because we have a different kind of humor but that I feel that some comments made were cynical and dismissive and quite frankly that it was abusive. The whole consultation was truly awful.This is when he asked the nurse to come in and I asked them to repeat the same things they had said before as the nurse was there. But obviously they didn't. I was made to read the MRI scan out loud to show that there is "nothing there" ( aka nothing threatening but still 3 x 5 cm lump is there). The doctor said I was just upset because they had said there is no lump. We ended this appointment with me being referred to another doctor because this doctor felt they couldn't continue the appointment with me. I had also asked to be referred to another doctor too. To be quite honest I felt even upset that the doctor saw my buttcheek so quickly - especially for pushing his finger to a spot that was painful and at the very beginning of our appointment to claim that they didn't see any lump. How is this possible?I respect highly any medical staff and always have. But this is truly unacceptable.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: chachawg94
title: Lack of equipment to help me live independently
body:
I am almost 80 years of age, live alone, and have no close relatives to help me, either physically or financially. Over the past few years I have asked for a stairlift from my Health Trust to help me have access to my bathroom, study and bedroom.  
I still carry out a great deal of voluntary work. In order to contribute to this work I need to have access to my study, so I applied for a stairlift through my GP who supported my application.  
I have arthritis in my spine, knees and feet and at times I cannot get upstairs because I fall backwards and hit my head on my hall floor. I have asked, under the freedom of information route, to be sent the local regulations which indicate the reasons why I cannot be given a stairlift. I have been informed by the OT department that I have enough rooms downstairs to convert them into a downstairs bathroom, a study and a bedroom and I should apply to the Housing Executive for a grant. I have in the past tried to avail of a grant to convert my bathroom upstairs into a shower room and been told that I cannot be given a grant because I did not currently meet the financial criteria. I have recently had to spend a considerable amount on house repairs therefore conversion of my downstairs rooms is not an option when a simple stairlift from the Trust would solve my problems. I am not dizzy so there is not a problem getting on and out of a stairlift chair to reach my bathroom.Government is keen that citizens can stay in their own homes, as opposed to being looked after in nursing homes, that they can get involved in community issues, and be independent. I also know of someone who was extremely wealthy, yet had been offered a stairlift. I have, and am still continuing to contribute to the local economy with payment of taxes. I worry that the issue of the stairs means that I may at some stage have a fall and die behind my front door. I asked my GP to intervene in my case which they kindly did, and have been informed that I should go through the Complaints process, years later!

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Andy124
title: Life-Changing Care
body:
[Very happy with 'Cleanliness']  
  
I've just returned home from my second stay in Forth Valley Royal Hospital in four weeks. After a rapid deterioration in my Crohn's, whereby I was vomiting in excess of twenty times per day, I sought advice from my GP.  
[Very happy with 'Staff attitude']  
  
[Very happy with 'Environment']  
  
[Very happy with 'Seeing the whole me']  
  
[Very happy with 'Introductions']  
  
[Very happy with 'Involved in decisions']  
  
[Very happy with 'Being listened to']  
  
[Very happy with 'Nurses']  
  
[Very happy with 'Care staff']  
  
[Very happy with 'Ambulance staff']  
  
[Very happy with 'Doctor']  
  
[Very happy with 'Other staff']  
  
The team there have been superb in managing my care, and diligently arrived at my home to administer a much-needed antiemetic. After a day of little or no change, my GP arranged for me to be admitted to FVRH. I would like to thank Drs Roemmle and Boddington for their amazing support, both at this time and throughout my time with the practice. On both occassions, I was taken to hospital by a superb ambulance crew from SAS - apologies, I didn't note their names, but they were friendly, supportive, and made two stressful journeys very easy.On both occassions, I was admitted to the Acute Assessment Unit and thereafter to Ward B32. Without exception, every member of staff who looked after me was kind, personable, generous, supportive, and the very epitome of person-centred care. While I offer apologies for anyone I have missed, I would like to say a huge thank you to the following:AAUEilidh, Maria, Elizabeth, Chloe, James, Lynette, Jodie, and Nicola.I'd like to say a special thank you to Dagmara, who clearly spotted that I wasn't at my best and spent some time with me to lift my spirits (and shared a very meaningful quote with me). B32Betsy, you run a stellar ward! Bridget, Claire, Sarah, Trisha, Monika, Adele, Charlotte, Shirley, Kevin, Fiona, the amazing Dawn, Karen, Jodie, Jamie, Teighan, Heidi, Carol Anne, Nicole, Jeanette, Grant, Maddy, Petts - each and every one of you supported my through my recovery and helped me get back on track with good humour, kindness, and respect. Thank you all. I also wanted to say sorry to Tracy on ward B32 for scaring her in the night! The dose of steroids I'm currently on is wreaking havoc with my sleep, and when Tracy came round to do obs one night, I nearly jumped out of my skin, terrifying her! Sorry Tracy - hope things are a bit quieter now that you've got rid of me! :-)Finally, I wanted to say a massive thank you to Jane on ward B32. Jane absolutely went above and beyond to support me. Whether it was with a kind word, a joke, or time taken to patiently discuss my fears around cannulas and injections, The time Jane spent with me discussing my injection phobia was truly life changing. Jane always helped make a long day that little bit more enjoyable. Thank you for everything. Throughout my stay, the hospital was clean, the food was excellent (good veggie choices and the soup was superb - so much so if they release a recipe book, I'm buying!) - top marks to everyone involved. To everyone involved in my care, from my GP surgery, to the amazing crews from SAS, to the staff in AAU and B32 - thank you all for everything you did for me. Currently on the road to a good and sustainaned recovery - I couldn't have done it without you.  
[Very happy with 'Food']

author: tauruszk83
title: A long sleepless night in excruciating pain.
body:
I had been suffering from earache for a week and had been using drops for a week from pharmacy. I’m in the extremely clinically vulnerable group as I’m highly immunosuppressed.  
I had just had my infusion that lowers my immune system and within 48 hours my earache felt like I was having a stroke. The pain is so severe I felt like I could pass out. My ear was hot, and wet and the pain was radiating down to my jaw and my neck. The skin in front of my ear on my cheek was completely numb and my head was about to explode. I’m always advised by my doctors that if I think I have an infection to get medical help right away after a history of sepsis and opportunistic infection.  
However, if it's not my usual GP then I have to phone NHS 24 and OOH. I feel like it could be made less stressful and a lot quicker. Every time I call I just feel like I’d be better rolling up in a ball and quietly dying in the corner.  
It was Saturday and I knew this infection was bad (I have 30 years experience of this by the way!) So I called NHS 24 and waited about 40 mins on the line and got through to a nice call handler. They were efficient to be fair which was a first and delightful. They spoke to a clinician and they said an OOH GP would call me back within 4 hours maximum. 5 hours later, I’m now in excruciating pain as I no longer have any prescription co-codomol left in my cupboard. (Paracetamol for this type of pain is like taking smarties). I am now running a fever and crying. I call back NHS24 and wait another 40 mins on the phone.  
By the time the second call handler takes all my details and asks the same questions again I’ve now been waiting for a call back for 6 hours. At this time pharmacies were still open and a simple electronic prescription to one of them for antibiotics and co-codomol would have taken 5 mins and I would have been more comfortable and jobs a good ‘un. But no.  
So the second call handler talks to another clinician for a long time and comes back to me and said that because my symptoms had gotten worse we’re going to get a different clinician to call you back. In another 4 hours!! Yes thats right. I’d have to wait another 4 hours even though my symptoms were worse and I’d already been waiting 6 without a call back as advised. ‘Say what now??’ Another 4 hours?! To ‘maybe’ get called back. This is the service of an immunocompromised patient with a severe and rapidly developing infection.  
I expressed my disbelief and the call handler went back to the clinician for another 10 mins while my eyes watered with the pain. They said that since I was not happy, they'd get someone to call me back within the hour. Oh I see, so it's my fault for being ‘unhappy’.  
I finally did get a call from a very jovial doctor from OOH. No apology for not calling me back when they should have the first time. I confirmed my symptoms (for the 5th time) and said they’d send a prescription for antibiotics to Sainsburys pharmacy which is now closed so I’ll have to let the infection spread and be in pain until the morning. I asked them for a prescription of co-codomal as this is what I have been previously prescribed and they said that I could buy my own at Sainsbury’s the 8/500 strength. Charming. I thought in Scotland prescriptions were free?  
I explained I normally get the stronger strength on prescription (they can easily check my records) and that I regularly take oxycodone for other pain but felt these were too strong to take for this type of pain. Still they refused. You see, when you have been chronically ill with many complications for 30 years like I have you get to know what painkillers work best with what type of pain. And the numb, earache and jaw pain radiating to my teeth and neck would have been made comfortable by 30/500 co-codomal. Not 8/500 in a patient who is opiate with experience. But what do I know? They said I could see how I go and can always call back. What?! Go through that ordeal and wait another 10 hours in pain while you call me back? Great advice. 5 stars.  
I go now to enjoy a long sleepless night in excruciating pain.

author: importernc84
title: My Last Pregnancy & nurses quick thinking
body:
I came into maternity and delivery on Thursday morning to be induced for my third and final pregnancy, I was ever so slightly overdue – I think 40 +3 and my doctors advised me that this would be the best course of action. They also did not want to wait any longer as my previous babies had been rather large.  
My experience with this pregnancy has been fantastic – all the nurses and midwives on the ward are brilliant and almost know what you need before you realise it yourself.  
This is going to sound strange but having no visitors has been a huge bonus for me. My boys were born pre-Covid and having the constant stream of visitors was quite overwhelming. I also found it nice to have more time with my daughter and not having to share her with anyone else. I also feel that having no visitors has given me more time to establish that close bond with my daughter and get to know her little mannerisms, even if she is only two days old. I think having no visitors would be especially beneficial to first time mums for learning how to breastfeed as it is quite tricky and a daunting prospect, before you even consider the awkwardness of your partners mother walking in while you’re trying to give your baby the best possible opportunity and start in life as possible.  
Everyone has been so amazing and I honestly couldn’t say anything bad about my experience. I had some issues post-birth with bleeding and needed rushed into emergency surgery, it was quite traumatic and honestly if it wasn’t for the nurses’ quick thinking and general skills in observing me I don’t think I would be here now. I lost about 2 litres of blood and had to have a blood transfusion – I feel great now because ordinarily I would be low on iron but with the transfusion, you honestly wouldn’t think I lost so much blood. The nurses have been really supportive since I was rushed to theatre and have been so attentive.  
I am so thankful to the nurses for their quick thinking and attentiveness as without them we wouldn’t be leaving in one piece, well I suppose two pieces now.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: KittyM
title: Homebirth and amazing midwives
body:
I had the most amazing team of homebirth midwives, who attended my home for all antenatal appointments. I felt that building a relationship with these midwives made me feel so much more relaxed and reassured about going into labour at home. They totally respected my wishes and birth plan, and supporting all the things that I had wanted for my first born baby.  
I had everything planned and organised, down to the snacks we had in the house.  
Things took a turn when I took covid a week before my due date, and was then told I would have to go to hospital, I believe this put my body under stress and it was just something that I hadn't wished for. When I started early labour and contractions started getting closer together which I contacted the Midwifey assessment unit, I was told that I would have to go into the hospital alone. Thankfully the homebirth team helped me in getting my husband into the delivery suite with me, as I was isolated anyway. The regulations within the hospital for having cold symptoms was absolutely ridiculous, however I did meet the most wonderful midwives in hospital who reassured me. I hadn't actually been in active labour and was sent home, and stayed in latent labour for another 24+ hours. I was able to have the homebirth team back on call as I was testing negative at home.  
When I went into active labour I had the most wonderful midwife Andrea come out to our home, she was the most gentle, caring lady anyone could ask for and was just so reassuring and comforting the whole way through labour at home.  
However I wasn't progressing anymore and I got my waters broke to find meconium. Therefore I was transferred to hospital via ambulance, where I spent the night still in very painful active labour and still not progressing. In the end I made the decision to have a C-Section and we finally got to meet our amazing, beautiful daughter. I am so grateful for the 2 lovely young midwives who looked after me during labour. However when I was transferred to the Midwifery Led Unit I was told my husband wouldn't be able to join me as I was still covid possible. I know this was no fault of any of the midwives working, but 100% down to the trust having ridiculous rules around covid. At a time when I needed my partner the most, to help support me and spend quality time with his daughter I was told I wasn't allowed it. In the end he got in for a short visit, but this totally made me an emotionally wreck and having a mini meltdown before I was able to see him. I felt so isolated and as if I was the plague when I was in MLU, all because I had a cold a week before, which I no longer had symptoms when I went into labour. Thankfully we got home a couple of days later, and we were back as a family unit and able to all heal together.  
I am so thankful for the homebirth team and I cannot recommend them enough. Paula was just a lady to work with and made everything so smooth. I 100% plan on a homebirth for my next baby and hope that I get to work with all the amazing midwives again. I would love to see the homebirth team grow more and more, promoting natural and comfortable births for women within the Southern Trust!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Elizabeth56
title: My experience as carer for my adult son
body: My son has been in the mental health system from teenage years. He is now 34. He has had several different anti-depressants and ect treatment twice. He has paid privately for trans cranial magnetic stimulation and other treatments like following an expensive ortho-molecular diet with consultation by private practitioners of this method. Nothing works. He is in a state of constant despair and has been hospitalised more times than I can remember. Every time there is a crisis eg self-harming I have to go through the very protracted system of ringing out of hours, who seem to know little about mental health, and they invariably refer him to casualty where he has waited up to 12 hours, climbing the wall in hysteria only to be referred to the mental health system he is already in. A fast track system is vital for suffering patients and carers like me who live in constant stress and do not need to be stressed by a health system. Recently he tried to harm himself in a way that meant protocol demanded out of hours GP got police involved. Whilst they were very good with my son they told me a great percentage of their time is taken up with similar cases. I don't feel that this is a good use of public resources as there were 6 police officers involved where possibly just one mental health crisis nurse was required. I feel that something needs to be done to rectify this model of reaching care as it does not currently work.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: moonmg95
title: My stay in the hospital
body:
On arrival, I was put at ease, taken to a consultation room where the process ahead of me was fully explained.  
Met various members of the team to make sure I understood what was going to take place.  
Taken to the anaesthesia room, rather nervous at this point, yet again, there was laughter and smiles all around. Definitely didn't want an epidural but nothing to it, the staff knew exactly what they were doing. I had sedation to help keep me calm. What seemed a short time I was in the recovery room where again the staff were amazing. I thought at some point I would get to a point whereby the staff would just treat me as a number, but there was no chance of that. I have never been to a hospital where there are so many kind-hearted and dedicated staff, where no matter what situation you found yourself in, any problems you were having with emotions, pain or simply not being able to reach your knickers, there was always a smiling face to help you.  
Night time staff were just as approachable, press your buzzer and genuinely someone will be at your bedside to help you.  
From cleaning staff(and yes the wards were immaculate) to theatre staff tthen onto the ward staff, I was looked after, I never felt I was being ignored, I have previously had treatment in a private care organisation but I can certainly say, the care at cannock hospital is second to none.  
Thank you to all the staff for making my stay as comfortable as possible. I have returned home with an aftercare package which was fully explained to me and even contact numbers should I need assistance.  
Oh and the food was just like perfectly home made food, all that is left to say is thank you to everyone, thankyou for looking after me.  
Other hospitals please take note, this is the way to run a hospital, well done to everyone.

author: Lets make a difference
title: Lincoln County Hospital
body:
Mum had lung cancer and wasn’t at end of life care, as it was contained with immunotherapy. However, she started to show toxicity in November 2021. She attended the Oncology Unit for her treatment and collapsed there. At that point she was vomiting so much she was unable to keep food and drink down for 4 weeks. She struggled to attend to toilet needs and subsequently collapsed with severe dehydration. The nurses were brilliant but the doctors sent her back home again.  
I received a call from a family member who was distressed as mum wasn’t coherent at home and hadn’t eaten for 6 weeks. I saw my mum and witnessed the state she was in. She had fluctuating capacity and when she did she said she couldn’t get to the upstairs toilet and had fallen and hit her head. She hadn’t released her bowels for a week and was peeing once a day when my dad tried to get her to the toilet. Her body was swelling up and when present, mum received a call from her oncologist, who was so rude to me I am appalled. They would speak to mum, who couldn’t get any words out by this stage. They said they will see her tomorrow and put the phone down. I rang Waddington Unit by this point and a fantastic member of staff said they needed mum in urgently, but they read back to me all the symptoms the unit knew about from 2 weeks prior to this, yet nothing was done.  
Mum was admitted and after a week, sent home with no care in place and the wrong medication. She couldn’t walk but didn’t even have a commode downstairs and the nurses that visited stated they didn’t know why they were there. Two days later she started vomiting again and we ended up back at the same place, this time within days. Again, we got her to hospital after a fight with the doctors who pushed for my dad to sign a DNR which he didn’t understand, as mum wasn’t at end of life cancer. He was so distressed. I turned up to the hospital in December and found the doctors had put mum into end of life care with not much discussion or anything with the family. By this point mum had given up mentally because of the treatment and she died 3 days later. The nursing staff were so short staffed, but were amazing and none of this is about them.  
I made a formal complaint about the lack of mum’s care 3 weeks prior to her death as this could have been avoided, but I was told to get mum’s permission which was so rude and wrong when she was unconscious. Then I got told I had to go to her executer of her will which is actually not legally correct. Nobody would allow this complaint to go through because they wanted me to prove I was her daughter. What is this? I am a professional in a mental health trust, and nobody would have been treated like that. We treat ALL family and carers with the compassion and respect they deserve. This Trust didn’t do anything of the sort.  
1: the lack of care given to mum when she collapsed was unprofessional, especially when my dad heard clearly that they weren’t helping her because of beds  
2: the lack of respect and courtesy of the Oncologist, who was so rude and appalling, it seemed that her dying was just another one off their caseload  
3: the lack of communication between departments, my poor dad received calls on mums phone after she died asking her to go for another Covid test before her next treatment. Nobody bothered to read her notes.  
4: the disgusting treatment of myself as her daughter and carer by this hospital.  
I am in conversation with the CQC about what has happened and will be seeking legal advice. I do not want anyone else to go through this. Covid is NOT an excuse.

author: cetuszr96
title: Thoughtful Staff
body:
I came in to hospital a few day ago with chest pain. I came up to Daisy Hill via ambulance and the ambulance staff were amazing, they were quick acting and very reassuring. When I arrived in the emergency department, I received some excellent care with the nursing and medical teams continuing right on from where the ambulance crew left off. The staff were very kind and thoughtful.  
I was then moved to the coronary care unit up on the male medical ward, and I cannot say a bad thing about the place. The doctors and nurses have been amazing and have been very supportive. Everything has been 100% and I couldn’t ask for any better care, the food has also greatly improved since the last time I visited the hospital

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: echofz95
title: Some areas that need improved
body:
I am a nurse practitioner of many years and I have very rarely been on the other side of the bed as a patient. My experience begins when I and my partner were visiting some family members and he took ill. He was rushed to the emergency department in Craigavon and he was diagnosed with renal and heart failure. He spent time in ICU in Craigavon and the care he received was amazing, he was then transferred to male medical in Daisy Hill – this was a difficult adjustment for him as he had gone from one-to-one care in ICU to not having his own nurse, I understand that this is no fault of the hospital, it was just a shock to him. He was in a side room for a while, and he felt that he had been left there to die. I informed the nurses of this and they moved him so that he could be seen and not feel ignored. He then later had a jugular access port put in as an outpatient procedure and we were sent home with the instructions to head to Craigavon or phone 999 if there were any issues. Later that night I woke up and I was covered in his blood as the access port had leaked. We were rushed to CAH and he spent 15 hours in resus, after 8 hours they managed to get the bleeding under control and then they sutured the port in so it wouldn’t leak again. He never got what he ordered as he was on a low potassium diet, so I had to bring him in food to ensure he could eat without worrying if it could make his existing conditions worse. He was later discharged and now attends dialysis 3 times a week. This experience was very hard on me and it was a very anxious time for both of us, but any issues that arose were dealt with quickly and effectively and I commend the teams in Craigavon and Daisy Hill for that.  
Then a few weeks ago I came into the emergency department with severe shortness of breath, I was in the department overnight while a bed was being organised for me up on the ward. I was well looked after in the department and saw several doctors, they suspected I had pneumonia and started me on antibiotics and other medications. There was a lovely nurse in the red resus who made me feel at ease and she actually came to visit me later on the ward, I really appreciated this gesture.  
I was admitted to male medical, and I spent my first few hours in the coronary care unit before I was moved to a different ward. I unfortunately didn’t see a doctor until a few days later, when other patients had seen one. Over this time my breathlessness had gotten worse. I was then moved onto a cardioversion ward, and I was quite freaked out, I emailed colleagues and friends telling them I was scared I was going to die. After this occurred I received an apology from the nurse in charge and some of the doctors over how I had been treated.  
I had gone for my first CT and I couldn’t actually get the CT done as when I lay down my breathlessness got worse, I felt that at the time the staff thought I was just hyperventilating due to the confined space. It was then discovered that I had a large amount of fluid in my lungs and this was likely the cause of my breathlessness. I then had a chest tube fitted. With the tube fitted I found my mobility greatly decreased as the drain itself was quite heavy, I then needed help to wash myself so I asked a Healthcare Assistant to help me, but they just brought me a cardboard bedpan and a cloth, left these on my table and then walked off. I was appalled that that was the level of care I received from her and I informed the nurses about this incident and it didn’t happen again. One of my friends came in to visit and helped me wash, that I would say was my breaking point. Later that day I heard the doctors talking about neoplastic syndrome on the phone and saw that there were tumour markers on my bloods form, that was when I knew something was really wrong.  
The doctors came and informed me that they had found cancerous cells in the pleural fluid they drained and that they were the cells of secondary metastases, I was then sent down to gynae in female surgical to have biopsies carried out. The nurse there was amazing and sat with me when I got the news. My nurse on the medical ward sat with me and cried when they found out about the cancer. My best friend informed my family and we all cried together.  
I want to thank my doctors for the care and compassion they have treated me with, it is truly unbelievable, I’m grateful for them starting me on the cancer care pathway. The pharmacists and cleaners have been so kind (one cleaner left me up a tea cake after the incident with the bedpan). The nurse in charge is honestly fantastic, the epitome of what a nurse should be.  
The only things I think could be improved is that the nursing feels very task orientated and that I feel that it would be very beneficial to have a psychologist there when patients are given bad news for patients to talk to  
If you asked me a week ago what I thought, wouldn’t have been so positive but this last week has truly made me grateful for the staff here.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: giraffepf93
title: Nurses stand out
body:
I have been having recurrent UTI’s ever since I got Covid last year, I came up to the Emergency Department after my GP referred me. I found this process to be quite simple and efficient. I was seen very quickly and overall I had a positive experience. All the members of staff down in the department have been lovely and have answered any questions myself or my mum had.  
I was moved up to the female surgical ward and everyone here has been so nice to me. The care I have been receiving is second to none. All the nurses are fantastic but Karen and the Student Nurse Clare have stood out to me. But overall they are all amazing.  
The food isn’t great, but it is edible and can be quite nice at times. I have heard good things about the mince so I am looking forward to trying it tonight and the chicken I had yesterday was delicious

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: electric2022
title: Interaction with the urologist
body:
My husband has been under the care of Mr Raju on and off for the last 20 or so years. He has been exemplenary in his interaction with us and has been able to explain procedures with pictures and drawings without putting any pressure.  
He has now agreed to surgical intervention and we have confidence in Mr Raju  
[Unsure about 'Seeing the whole me']  
[Unsure about 'Involved in decisions']

author: reticulumds97
title: The staff are top notch
body:
I came up to Daisy Hill via ambulance, I was in agonising pain and knew that something was seriously wrong. The staff in the department were brilliant but they need more doctors and nurses there to help them so they aren’t overwhelmed. Yes there were long waits but I knew that was likely when I arrived and I didn’t mind waiting.  
I was moved up to the ward to await surgery to get my gall bladder removed. The staff are top notch and I couldn’t praise them enough. My experience up here has been brilliant and all the staff standout, but Deirdre has been especially kind and caring.  
The food is good, I can’t really complain about it.  
The one thing I’ll say is this hospital needs to stay open, I honestly don’t know what I would do without it here, and so many people make use of the emergency surgery service here. They are doing such a good job and they don’t get the credit they deserve

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: honey54
title: My life has changed for the better
body:
I had a skin condition it took six years for my GP Surgery to refer me.  
I had an appointment with Dr Haddon at RCHT Dermatology and within three months my life had changed. I had to have a biopsy but was made to feel at ease during the process as I do get anxious.  
Now after two years my life has completely changed for the better. I would like to say a huge huge thank you to Dr Haddon who is an amazing Dr who cares and understands patients also a huge thank you to the team. We need more Doctors like this.

author: octansmj43
title: Better communication is needed
body:
I came in around 8 days ago with some really bad pain in the back of my head. I had no issues in A and E and all the staff were lovely. I was moved up to the female surgical wall and it has been fine, I’ve found that being a medical patient on a surgical ward has been strange, all the surgical patients see their doctors daily when I think I’ve seen mine 3 times in total.  
There seems to be an issue with communication as I had a lumbar puncture and the doctor came to see me after it, and didn’t know that I had had it. The next day another doctor came around and asked again if I had the lumbar puncture. I am waiting for neurology to see me, but apparently there based in Craigavon so I don’t really know what I’m doing. I have spoken to the nurses about this and I really appreciate how kind they have been to me. Angela has stood out to me out of the whole nursing staff, she is always kind and compassionate and leaves you feeling cared for.  
I feel that there needs to be more communication within the medical team, both internally between themselves and with patients. I feel that I don’t really know where I stand and I wonder if I’ve just wasted 8 days doing nothing, I am honestly at the point where I am looking at private MRI scans as I just want to know what is wrong.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: encryptionzf97
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Kind and very helpful staff
body: Since coming into level 4 I have been overwhelmed by the level of care I have received has been amazing. All the nurses and members of staff I have encountered have been so kind and very helpful. Veronica has been especially helpful and has made sure my hearing aids don’t go missing. There is nothing in my opinion that needs improved.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Pepsicara
title: Very satisfied with everything
body: I had my hip replaced recently. Everything went as planned, aftercare from nursing staff excellent. Physio care good. Discharged two days later. Very satisfied with everything.

links.id: very well looked after and cared for

author: coinpq86
title: Quick and efficient
body: Removal of implant was quick and efficient, however I was 20 minutes late going into my appointment. Frustrating when it was the first appointment of the day and I could see & hear staff talking about their weekends.

author: teenmama
title: Having my baby
body: I was induced to have my baby in Altnagelvin Hospital at the start of December 2021, being a young mummy I was absolutely terrified and had no idea what to expect. I had the loveliest midwife Brogan and she made me feel so reassured and safe, she made my experience brilliant and I definitely couldn’t have done it without her. Thank you so much Brogan!!!

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: SundayNightVisit
title: Efficient, helpful and kind
body: Our granddaughter dropped a heavy brick on her right foot, bruising 3 toes. It was very painful for her, and we feared that there may have been at least one broken bone. With some trepidation, we took her to Craigavon Area Hospital, but instead, we were very impressed with the care and attention our granddaughter received. Every member of staff we came in contact with was efficient, helpful and kind to her/us; she was thoroughly examined by several members of staff, each of whom knew how to work with a distressed child who was in pain, helping to put her at ease. We had expected to be at the hospital for most of the evening however from arrival to leaving was around 75 minutes which we thought was very impressive! We are very grateful to Blossom/CAH for their care and attention.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: dicanio
title: Breathless on exertion
body:
Breathless on exertion. GP sent me to Watford General Hospital to rule out a pulmonary embolism.  
Communication very bad between GP and hospital but eventually seen in Ambulatory Care Unit and had fantastic care. Many thanks to Van, nurse in charge, Donna, the AP who did all my tests, Dr Ejas whom I pestered to let me go home and phoned me later with my normal blood test results and further advice- and also to Margaret the receptionist who was kindness itself to me and everyone else who was there.

author: coordinationdm44
title: Rude and dismissive staff member
body: Went to a&e feeling very unwell and was triaged by a staff member who I found very rude. Seemingly I wasn’t the only person to have a bad experience with them as another patient wanted to complain too. Made me feel very uncomfortable and almost feel bad about coming and would put me off coming again.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: Mummy64
title: My health visitor
body: My health visitor Ann goes above and beyond the call of duty. Nothing is an inconvenience to her. She is so helpful. She truly is the best most thorough and professional health visitor I have ever had. I am so thankful to have her.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Great Care and attention
body: Just had a full hip replacement at this hospital can I can not find one fault with the care I had here from everyone I had contact with I want to say a heartfelt thank you to everyone involved with my operation and after care.

title: Amazing hospital
body: The surgeon and anaesthetist were so professional but very understanding, informative and calming. All of the nurses and everyone that I came across for my operation were wonderful. Such a kind friendly professional hospital.

title: First class service.
body: Made to feel at ease and greeted by a smile. Everyone was very friendly and helpful. I was apprehensive and nervous when I arrived but that soon disappeared because of the amazing staff. I can’t speak high enough and can’t thank them enough.

title: Eye injections
body: Unlike cataract operations I have had eye injections and spread over three months and ongoing, the nurses and all who attended to my needs on the day were very helpful, I don’t think the care and treatment could have been any better.

title: Exellent physiotherapist
body: He was a kind and caring person and thorough in his treatment and having recieved my 6 sessions, the pain is much improved and i have more movement in my neck

readBy.name: Kent Community Health NHS Foundation Trust

title: Excellent Practice
body: We joined The Brooke Surgery as we were so frustrated with our previous surgery. Best decision we made. It's so easy to get advice speak to a doctor or nurse & get a face to face appointment if required. All the  staff & Doctors are so professional & helpful can't praise them highly enough. The system they use AskmyGP is so easy to use & someone contacts you the same day. Excellent service we will be recommending The Brooke Surgery to all our family & friends.

title: Professional, fast service
body:
I just wanted to express my thanks to the medical staff and team at the dermatology clinic at Cramlington as well as my GP and the multi disciplinary team that work behind the scenes to coordinate this efficient service 
I was fast tracked very quickly and dealt with in a professional and caring way. I had tried to use my private health care provider who could not even get me seen, lots of red tape which you don’t need when facing a potential life threatening diagnosis 
NHS fast track Newcastle Hospitals Trust is truly fast, all the stress was taken away knowing you’re in good hands as soon as your GP refers you, whatever the outcome. 
Thank you I received positive news which is a huge relief but even if the outcome was different I knew I would be in safe hands. 
I appreciated this service more than I can express in my review.

readBy.name: The Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Always been wonderful
body: I’ve been with Quayside for about 3 years now and I’ve never had any issues. If my little girl is poorly then she’s seen on the day and the doctors are always so kind and friendly towards her. They take the time to explain what they think and they never seem to rush you. I have never had any issues with my repeat prescriptions, the reception staff have always been great and I feel confident with the care provided. I’ve seen most of the GPS at one time or another and all are really genuine and friendly. Thanks for being such a great practice!

title: Great treatment
body: Great treatment received few times in attendance to dressings clinic most polite and thorough friendly staff most helpful nothing was any trouble

title: Extremely helpful reception staff
body:
I was so grateful to the reception staff in Hawthorn house who was exceptionally helpful when I was struggling in finding the unit and becoming  late for my infusion appointment for monoclonal antibody treatment referred to the unit by the nhs test and trace service. The nurses also offered me a drink as I was anxious on arrival. 
Kind and Wonderful staff out there at Hawthorn house !!
I felt half better already even before the treatment was given. 
 NHS is so proud of you guys and  I wish you all safe and well .

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

title: Great practice
body: I can not thank the friendly staff enough so kind friendly helpful and care was outstanding and thorough nothing was any trouble for them so helpful made to feel at ease thank you

title: Fantastic service
body:
Have had numerous occasions the past few months where either I, or family members have needed to obtain appointments.
A short wait to get through, various helpful navigators have listened and offered either telephone calls or face to face appointments (our choice)
Each clinician has responded in a comprehensive manner, following up when needed.
Honestly I can not fault the service we have been given.
Keep up the good work, during continuing hard times, you’re all doing an amazing job.
Thank you

author: orangeps97
title: Well looked after
body: I tested positive for covid and was feeling gradually worse. We called out of hours who sent an ambulance. The ambulance crew were so friendly and understanding and clear on each thing we did. The staff in a&e even with being covid positive were approachable and friendly. 2 days later and the out of hours nurse that called on the first day called back to see how I was as she was really concerned after the first call. That was really thoughtful and meant a lot, even with the busy departments I was well looked after and at home now recovering with medication and direction to contact straight away should I deteriorate.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

title: Superb
body:
Went on with a swollen head and swollen face.
The staff were fantastic.
I was there was 5 hrs but they kept checking on me and they explained everything.

readBy.name: South Tees Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: Woodie
title: Excellent treatment
body:
I was recently operated on by Mr Donat, a consultant in the western general hospital urology department, to remove cancerous tumours. Prior to that, I had attended an appointment with him for an examination and a discussion about the way forward. Subsequent to the operation I again met with him for a check up. I was very impressed (and grateful to him!) by him for the excellent treatment I received throughout the whole process. The same applies to the whole team involved: nurses, radiographers, anaesthetists ,secretaries, and everyone else I encountered.  
I am delighted to say that my recovery went very well and would like to express my sincere thanks to all.

author: memberzh84
title: Professional, efficient, kind & caring
body: I recently attended the Hysteroscopy Clinic, Queen Margaret Hospital, Dunfermline. The procedure I had today was unpleasant but the care I received was excellent. Dr Monaghan & both Nurses were professional, efficient, kind & caring. They put me at ease & even made me a cup of tea after. Thank you so much.

title: Fabulous care
body: I recently underwent gall bladder removal surgery and was admitted onto the day care ward. The level of care I received, from the surgeon,  to the nurses on the ward was second to none. The surgeon explained the whole procedure and was really reassuring.  He came to check on me promptly following the surgery. The day care ward is run so efficiently and all the team were so kind and caring. The staff never stop on that ward. It was also immaculately clean, with cleaners visible all day. Thank you for making my experience a good one.

title: Give them a break
body: Hearing people complain about NHS services at this time makes me cross but also highlights how people abuse the system. I have been satisfied with my interactions at this surgery and would like to thank ALL staff for their hard work and give some positive feedback as I am sure they all take a lot of abuse from people that have no idea what pressure you are all experiencing.  So well done and thank you to everyone providing a service at this surgery.

title: Very caring
body:
I initially phoned to ask if I could be seen as I felt unwell.
The lady I spoke to was very kind as I was a bit emotional.
On arrival I was dealt with quickly and with great understanding.
I was sorry to have had to be seen when they are so busy but was met with complete kindness and received the help I needed.
Thank you all so much.

readBy.name: Lincolnshire Community Health Services NHS Trust

author: SophieO
title: Diagnosis and useful treatment
body:
I have suffered from a compulsion/tic/twitch since childhood, triggered by loss and grief, which limited my ability to sleep at night, but also share a bed with my partner. Often leaving me with insomnia, anxiety, depression and just feeling very confused, as it wasn't until recently that I opened up about what I was going through. I never knew that it was a tic, I just thought I was acting out weirdly and it made me so embarassed and ashamed for a long time. I often declined anything that required staying at another person's house or sharing a room due to this, which limited me a lot on experiences.  
However, when I contacted my GP, I was referred to Inclusion Thurrock, and also Mind. I am known to them for having multiple different treatments, but I had never opened up about my true issue, I danced around what was really bothering me for a long time.  
I recently suffered a trauma which left me experiencing the compulsion multiple times a night, which would progress into panic attacks and suicidal thoughts.  
About 4 years ago, my previous boyfriend had taken his own life and blamed me for what he did. For someone who was already suffering with mental health issues, this was such a dark period of my life, my compulsion had never been worse as it had been the past 4 years, I felt like giving up, I couldn't share a bed with my partner anymore, if I did I was dangerous to sleep next to as I would hit out and jump, squeeze him really hard or shout really loudly. I didn't know how to explain my problem to anyone as I felt like it was so unique and unusual, nobody would know what to do to help me. Before giving up, I decided to approach my GP one more time and seek help.  
The process was brilliant, I was diagnosed with OCD within a few weeks which gave me clarity, it allowed me to be able to research the condition and find out how so many people related to the same problem I was having or similar.  
I then had some group sessions online which were like an anonymous chat room, to prepare for CBT. Inclusion never left me waiting for a long time for any help, there were always options whilst I was waiting for my CBT to start. As well, Mind representatives called me weekly to see how I was doing, and to offer wellbeing experiences.  
When I was paired with Louise for my CBT, I had already engaged in many other different sessions which had helped me prepare for CBT, so it wasn't so overwhelming. Louise was very patient, often our weekly sessions didn't relate at all to my original problem, she catered for what I had been going through that week and prioritised the immediate risks over the long term issues which I found very useful. However, I have also managed to reduce my compulsion a lot since our sessions, as well as recognising other behaviours and thoughts which were problematic, and managed to overcome some of those as well. Louise also sourced other helpful treatments for me which I am waiting for. I have felt so comfortable opening up to all the members of the Inclusion team, and I am so grateful for their support and professionalism. They always try to fit around my schedule even when I have last minute cancellations, they have never made me feel like a burden or an inconvenience. They treat you like an individual and always remember nice things about you to uplift you, it's very personal and empowering.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

title: Very Improved Reception
body:
Very pleased to see new staff at the reception. I visited the reception to request an appointment as the telephone service failed to take the call. The two assistants at the reception were incredibly helpful, clear and even though they were very busy, they explained the new app and also provided me with an appointment.
I had been a frustrated patient for many years in this surgery as the previous receptionists were very rude. 5 stars to the new staff, well done!

author: fluteqx89
title: Wonderful service
body:
After a 2 day stay in QMC on ward 4, having been diagnosed with having had a "small stroke" I came back home where my husband who has Parkinson's disease was being cared for by one of my daughters, over the weekend. She was replaced the next day by the other daughter.  
You feel vulnerable when you come out of hospital so a lovely surprise to have contact made by the stroke team. It was so supportive to have speech therapy and physiotherapy to help get speech and movement improved, and so good of them to make all the visits in covid times.  
The help I received was immense and good to have any improvement measured from beginning to end. I cannot thank them all enough for what they did and I am extremely grateful for their efforts and kindness, particularly Alice for physio. It is a wonderful srevice that the stroke team give, thankyou so much.

title: Five Star care from all staff
body: This is my first experience of undergoing surgery, so was very nervous. All the staff in every area looked after me completely in every way, it was 5star care from the day I arrived until I was discharged. The follow up after care continues just the same. Thank you so much everyone. You are amazing.

title: Incredible practice
body:
I have being using this practice for many years and the level of care I receive every single time is exceptional. 
The receptionists are all marvellous and truly empathetic. The level of pressure they are under never shows in their commitment to deliver great service. 
All the doctors are superb and really listen and I never feel like I am being rushed or a burden. I am very grateful that they all care and are so supportive and are so focussed on getting me well and able to go back to work. Thank you all so very much for looking after me so well all these years. I appreciate it must be very difficult but you all do a fantastic job.

author: February18
title: Hernia repair operation
body: I waited a long time for my op due to covid. I eventually had my pre op by brilliant staff at ayr university hospital. Had PCR test done at crosshouse hospital. I had my op under general anaesthetic at day surgery at ayr. The nurses, anaesthetist and both surgeons were fantastic. I was well treated. Well informed. Well looked after by this fantastic team. Arrived at 8 am. back home by 3 pm. well worth the wait. Brilliant team. Many thanks.

title: Very good experiences of this practice
body: I have always received a highly professional service from this practice. The reception staff are friendly and helpful and the GPs listen, explain and refer you appropriately. Getting through to the practice is fine and although appointment times are delayed that is the case everywhere currently. They always ask if you need to be seen urgently.  I think the team have been doing a great job under what has been very challenging circumstances and I want to say thank you.

title: Speedy, compassionate care
body: Over the last 2 months I have had cause to have an in-person Doctor's appointment, an in-person Nurse's appointment, a phone call with a Doctor and to liaise with the Referrals team. The availability of appointments was excellent (the Nurse appointment was for the same day!) and every individual has been professional, friendly, compassionate and keen to do the best for me. Investigations of my symptoms are continuing so I am anticipating further need of care but I have every confidence in this team of people.

title: Great care
body: all who attended to me had considerable care and attention.especially when I was undergoing hip surgery, the anethatist, and surgeon, informed me all the way.

author: Relieved&Grateful_Nurse
title: Compassionate caring and professionalism
body: Just home after a 3 night admission to the Qeuh, from all the nurses in A&E to ARU1 to Ward 5B, Ct Scanning and MRI, The Stroke Team and Medical team, the Porters, The Kitchen staff, the ward Domestics, the Clerical staff. I can't thank everyone involved in my care enough for their kindness, compassionate caring and professionalism. You guys all rock. From the bottom of my heart thank you.

title: Great experience
body: I had an appointment today for a pap smear test. The Nurse informed me about contraceptive methods, explained all the procedures carefully and was very kind. I am very happy with this appointment.

title: Fantastic practice
body: I have been a patient in this practice for many years and feel in this time where gp practices a getting a bad name, that our practice has always been and remained during all covid restrictions accessible to their patients and particularly lately when I have see a few different doctors in the wider nhs for pain and felt I have not been listened to however a particular gp  at our practice first time I saw him has listened and actually given me a diagnosis and treatment which has given left me pain free for the first time in over a year, as a nurse myself I know how important it is to listen to your patients and I feel that this practice does just this so well done

author: Karen45
title: Gynaecology appointment
body:
I went to my doctor and was referred to gynecology at Stobhill hospital. I'm still waiting for an appointment.  
I've been told to do pelvic floor exercises. Frustrating not knowing what's going to happen. I've lost a lot off weight from 2020 - I used to be 14 stone. I'm now 10 and a half st.  
How long will I have to wait?  
I'm confused about my sexuality even though I was born female.

title: Amazing professional support
body:
My Dad attended your Ambulatory Care Department under advice from his GP. The Department was at full capacity but within 4 hours he had been taken to x-ray, had bloods taken, been examined, advised regarding change of dosage of medication, been assured that everything was ok and discharged. My Dad has poor health and was treated with kindness and had everything explained to him thoroughly. 
Thank you for all the treatment he was given by your staff, including receptionists, nurses, porters and doctors.

title: Great practice
body: Very supportive staff, receptionist was very polite and nurses were excellent and very supportive. My phone consultation with my GP was friendly, professional and life saving. I have never had a negative interaction with this practice.

title: Wonderful care
body: Admitted through A&E following a slip on mud at Basildon Park.  Following an operation for a new hip and broken shoulder,I was admitted to Hurley ward, then to Emmer Green ward.  I would just like to applaud everyone I came into contact with, doctors, clinicians, Physio’s, nurses, and porters.  The care and kindness were exceptional from everyone, greeted everywhere with a smile and kind efficiency, making a painful experience much more bearable.  Thank you to all.

author: Frankcb1
title: The staff were professional and polite
body: Arrived at clinic in plenty time was booked in which took about 15 minutes. The procedure was explained and I had a consent form to sign. The nurse who booked me in was polite and freindly.  After a slight delay I was taken to the procedure room, the two nurses who took me there were polite and chatted to me.  Met the person who was doing the procedure and he put me at ease with his relaxed attitude. Procedure was carried out under intrevenous pain relief and was over in about 15 mins. All staff that I was involved with were professional and polite. After some tea and toast I was allowed home after about 45 minutes.  Couldnt fault the care and attention I received from addmission to discharge

title: Excellent practice
body: Ive been apart of this practice for over 16 years now , staff and doctors are really friendly , i would recommend this practice to friends and family , ive never had any problems with this practice everyone there are so welcoming

title: A great customer experience.
body:
From Alan White - I've been seeing Dr Pilat for the last few months regarding a few issues and would like to say what a great experience it has been for me. He was very thorough with his diagnosis an absolute pleasure to see, which coupled with his wonderful caring personality, put me a complete ease and made my visits that more easy.

From Mrs A White - I would also like to extend my thanks to Dr Mead for her brilliant service. Very thorough and willing to listen.

author: bjk21
title: The whole team are wonderful
body: I have been under Good Hope Orthodontic department for over 4 years now and I am soon to be discharged. The whole team are wonderful and have always been so welcoming and helpful at each visit. I would like to especially thank Anita who has been excellent and her work has helped improved my confidence massively! Thank you all!

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

author: empathysg99
title: Efficient and friendly service
body: I fell and broken my wrist. The staff and services provided the whole time have been brilliant. Efficient and friendly. So kind and extremely skilled professionals. Couldn’t fault any of them. Thank you.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust
South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Emmrd63
title: Thankful that I was given a chance
body: I now feel extremely hopeful thank you Rebecca I'm so Grateful for everything you do and so thankful that I was given a chance from advocacy Wales to help me

author: Emmrd63
title: Help and support
body: Thank you for all your help and support to get here. I'm very happy with the place too! It was worth fighting for!!!

author: Sammy71xx
title: Treatment for warts
body: Nurse examined me and doctor prescribed cream for treatment

author: Disgusted daughter and nurse
title: Crew member was rude
body: 86 year old mother with a previous history of biliary sepsis leading to her almost losing her life on the last occasion developed symptoms that I recognised could be the beginning of another episode. Ambulance was called, on arrival one of the crew members was rude and suggested that we had called the ambulance for social care reasons. My mother is looked after at home with no care package and family input only, she is well looked after and being a trained nurse of 47 years myself would never dream of calling an ambulance for this reason. Left us shocked.

author: juneec33
title: Broken tooth after Surgery
body:
I had a Hysterectomy at the Belfast City hospital in Belfast at the end of Jan and it was successful. In the process my front tooth was got cracked and broken as a result of the intubation procedure carried out on me.  
I was discharged some days later with a verbal apology for what happened and a promise to get my tooth fixed by NHS Dental and I should expect a call or a mail in a few days. Fast forward 4 weeks alter, I have neither got any call or mail in the post to that effect.  
I have tried reaching the Belfast City Hospital Gynae ward and secretaries and left a ton of voice messages ,but still no response. I had no other choice than to tell of my experience and hopefully can get some form of closure or help on the way forward.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: giftqr49
title: First time having an endoscopy
body: Felt nervous and anxious but was soon made to feel at ease with the wonder staff everything was really professional and thorough on time and dealt with swiftly. The staff were so friendly and upbeat it the experience so much better

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

title: Heatherwood Hospital
body: Just been to an appointment at Heatherwood Hospital gynaecological department. The staff were brilliant; reassuring, friendly & they took the time to explain things to me. If anyone has an upcoming appointment, please be assured that you are going to be in very good hands. Thank you Heatherwood.

title: Outstanding Practice
body:
I've been a patient at this practice for many years now, and by far it's the best practice I've been a patient at. 

The reception staff are always very polite, friendly and always go out of their way to assist you. The GP's are great, always listen to your concerns, and always manage to re-assure you everything will be okay. 

Even throughout the pandemic, the surgery have been amazing. 

Thank you all so very much Carepoint Practice.

title: Fantastic Nurse Practitioners
body: Had fantastic service by 2 Nurse Practitioners.  They made me feel at ease and talked to me throughout my procedure, explaining everything to me and having general chit chat.

title: Fantastic Nurse Practitioners
body: Had fantastic service by 2 Nurse Practitioners.  They made me feel at ease and talked to me throughout my procedure, explaining everything to me and having general chit chat.

title: Highest care offered
body:
I went in for a 'green light laser' procedure in February, the care I received was outstanding. I had to re admitted because of a complication and the 2 nurses that looked after me were very understanding and went out of their way to make me feel comfortable. They even exceeded their normal working hours to make sure I was ok. 
I would like to thank them, they were fantastic and its so good to know that angels do really exist.

title: Caring people
body:
After struggling with uncontrolled asthma symptoms post covid the practice asthma nurse has made a huge difference to my quality of
Life. Thankyou so much

title: CT Scan
body: I arrived for my CT scan and was told that it had been cancelled and rearranged (not directly by South Bristol Community Hospital) but I hadn't been informed of this.  My heart sunk as my partner and I had taken the day off work but the Receptionist was extremely helpful and said she would speak to the Radiographers.  The Radiographers fitted me for my scan and were friendly and helpful making me feel at ease.  Thank you so much for being efficient and making my life easier during difficult times.

title: Faultless service
body: First of two cataract ops at Norwich branch, warm friendly staff, Visited 4 departments prior to op all excellent service. also good coffee ( free ) in reception area

title: Excellent practice and doctors
body: Dr S- senior partner has done an amazing job in terms of recruiting new staff and doctors, and has provided a fantastic service to me and my family. I would not be alive were it not for him. He has worked tirelessly through the pandemic to help all his patients, and I cannot thank him and the surgery enough. Well done and Thank you.

title: Excellent caring practice
body:
Thank you for the exceptional care shown to my elderly mother and father-in law.  The practice has outstanding receptionists and extremely caring doctors.  Nothing is too much trouble for them, and they happily deal with all the continuing issues we’re dealing with as a family. 
You’re making a difficulty time a little easier for us.

title: Fantastic service
body:
I have had 2 cataract operations in the last 12 weeks.
I was treated at Bedford .I am beyond impressed with the attention I received.
Today I returned for the check up on my second cataract op.
The service I received in all of my visits was  way beyond my expectations .The reception staff are welcoming , putting people at ease .The attention to detail is amazing .The whole outfit seems to be run so smoothly , care given at all times to every patient .All my questions were answered , everything was explained , nothing was rushed , nothing hurried .
I now have the most amazing sight thanks to the team at SpaMedica .I must add that the level of cleanliness is beyond impressive .Coffee or tea supplied , even a packet of biscuits .
I want to thank everyone across the board at Bedford , you are all amazing .

title: Great GP
body: I went to see my GP yesterday  ... all GPS should be like this lady. She was very thorough during the appointment and covered all avenues possible to try and resolve and make better my current situation. A kind and caring GP ...

title: Great service
body: Wonderful speedy service today at Orthopaedics and X-ray at Southend Hospital. Such friendly, professional staff . Thank you all for a great experience.

readBy.name: Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust

title: Great doctors and staff
body: Left an email requested an appointment witch was answered straight away and got seen the same day brilliant service

title: Worth the wait
body:
