Despite having a long waiting time in A&E, as many others have experienced, the care I received from the team was second to none. Please don't be put off by waiting times, it is no individuals fault. 
The majority of my stay was spent in the AMU, however I could not select this from the list of departments when leaving this review. 
Once I was admitted to the Acute Medical Unit the care and treatment I received was faultless. Friendly staff who listen and acknowledged the patient's needs, 3 meals a day, always on time, great quality food too. I found myself missing some of the regular meals I had come to look forward to!
I cannot mention any names of specific staff, but the general attitude of every single member of staff I encountered was inspiring. I'd also like to thank the Gastroenterology department for efficient aftercare.

In summary, to any member of the public reading this, don't be put off by waiting times, it is unavoidable in the current circumstances and every person in that building wants to help you get better. 

Thank you Hereford County Hospital for quite literally saving my life

title: Very good pratice
body:
Hazelden is doing a wonderful service to the patients throuhgout the Panemic includings blood tests and other normal tests.
I very muh appreiated the effforts put in by the Dotors, nurses, assistants  and the whole staff.  Prayers to all off you!!
Many many thanks for your excellent services

title: Our Nan can't manage the appointment system
body:
The positive reviews are clearly all from those who have no problems with confusion, or severe mental distress, or learning disability. And who can clearly access the internet and have no data problems and don't have to struggle with costs of PAYG phones. 

My Nan cannot cope with this system. The GP knows this and would never have thought telephoning her this way for an appointment before covid. And in case they had missed that she is struggling badly with her health they have been automatically contacted by NHS 111, by ambulance services and by the various A&E's who have to keep attending because she is confused or fallen or her mental health has got worse.

She has tried calling but no GP has arranged to see her and they should have. In the past the GP held back appointments to be able to book in patients directly but we don't think this system is operating anymore. 

We rang to try and get an appointment for a medication review but for some reason no appointments at all were available ( not even a couple of weeks ahead). And yes the receptionist was lovely. On that occasion we left our numbers as family for a call back from the duty doctor but no one called us . Instead they called our Nan who couldn't manage to get to the phone ( no message left but 1471 showed). Which demonstrates the problems people face.

None of us doubt that there are lovely receptionists and doctors. The problem is that far too many cannot access a telephone based appointment system and so never get to see the lovely doctor. There is clearly a divide and it feels that if you are the worried well of Kentish Town or just very assertive and techy you will get to see a GP. If you are severely disadvantaged in some way you won't.

Let's also hope the new online system meant to be up and running but already unavailable is better than the previous one which is simply a very poor algorithm that barely includes the most common ailments . Anything that self care isn't appropriate for you are directed to phone the GP ! So, we hope that the new system will let us actually communicate with the GP directly and get our Nan the face to face appointment she needs. 

The NHS is meant to be there for everyone on an equal footing. The lovely reviews are from those for who telephone and video systems work . My Nan is 83 and can't manage . 

Maybe the patient group who the website says meets with the practice can address this  as this has been her GP for decades?

title: sneaky way of managing waiting lists
body:
I've been an in-patient and out-patient at Bassetlaw hospital, and have no complaints about the care I have received from wonderful medical staff.
But administratively they don't seem so caring (or maybe they are just in chaos).
Today (26th January) I received a letter inviting me for an Xray requested by my GP.  That letter is dated 15th February and postmarked (second class) on the 24th February.  So my invitation to this appointment has arrived by the very last post that could possibly have got me to the appointment.  Of course a bit more notice (which would appear to have been available in view of the date of the letter) would have been welcome and increased my chances of getting to this appointment.
But this has been going on for a very long time !  In 2008 my wife got an appointment letter which was actually delivered _after_ the date of the appointment.  That letter had no postmark so we can't tell when it was posted, but the letter from the consultant (removing her from his list for missing the appointment) arrived fast enough !
It's time to take a good look at how they notify patients of appointments, I think.

readBy.name: Doncaster and Bassetlaw Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: The worst receptionist
body: The receptionist are rude, with an attitude, they don’t care about you, inhuman and unhelpful. They tried to call me back but I didn’t have time to answer because they hang up so quickly… I don’t understand how they can work like that.

title: Quick and efficient
body: I visited the Cumberland Centre, in Damerel Close, Devonport on Sunday 27th Feb 2022. I had an infection in my right ear. The whole experience was friendly, professional and efficient, and surprisingly quick.

title: Disappointing
body:
I’ve had issues getting repeat prescriptions, chasing up test results which have been received by the surgery but not communicated to me through app or any other means and had to make unnecessary visits because blood pressure readings weren’t recorded when I have visited which has led to having to take extra time off work to deal with issues. Service is very dependent on the person that deals with your online request - sometimes amazing, sometimes the responses are rude/unhelpful. 

The online appointment booking service is great in principle but in reality means you have no control over appointments or who your appointment is with so there’s no continuity of care and therefore it’s not efficient as you end up explaining issues over and over again.

title: Excellent treatment
body: My experience was a positive one. I saw a consultant and had a breast cyst diagnosed and drained, following an x-ray and consultation all within the space of less than three hours. Very pleased.
